categories.description: Visit these twelve “must-see” sites for a glimpse into Skagway’s colorful past—and present.
categories.name: Highlights

media.alt: Large American hangs on flagpole on a windless sunny day.
media.caption: Large American hangs on 99-foot tall flagpole in center of parade ground. View is front the front of the Commissary.   Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Large American hangs on flagpole on a windless sunny day.

media.alt: Block House of First Fort
media.caption: Block House of First Fort

media.alt: Map Thumbnail for Bastion #5
media.caption: Map Thumbnail for Bastion #5
media.name: Map Thumbnail for Bastion #5

media.alt: Gazebo with panels
media.caption: Gazebo with three interpretive panels and an audio box describing the establishment of Fort Smith. Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Gazebo near First Fort (Includes 3 WS)

media.alt: 15 star and 15 stripe flying
media.caption: Originally, a new star and stripe were added for each new state. In 1817, a 15 star 15 stripe flag flew over the fort. Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Flag of First Fort

media.alt: Miss Laura’s a green Victorian two story building
media.caption: Miss Laura’s is Victorian building, former bordello, and Fort Smith's official welcome center. Not on Park property.  Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Miss Laura's Visitor Center

media.alt: River front park on a sunny day
media.caption: Park and open amphitheater that is the site of concert and special event throughout the year. Not on Park property.  Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: River Front Park

media.alt: Aerial view of bastion #2 on a sunny day
media.caption: Aerial view from parade ground bastion #2 location. The bastion was converted to Quartermaster’s building. Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Bastion #2 (includes Initial Point Marker and Belle Point Historical Marker)

media.alt: Barracks/ Courthouse/ and Jail on a sunny day.
media.caption: Visitor Center from the northeast side.Closest part of the build the old barracks later jail and courthouse. The far end it the second more modern jail completed in 1888.  Photo Credit: FOSM NPS
media.name: Barracks, Courthouse, Jail (WS) / Visitor Center

media.alt: Reproduction of gallows use to hang 86 men.
media.caption: Reproduction gallows on the site of the original gallows where 86 men were executed.  Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: The Gallows (includes 2 WS)

media.alt: The gazebo on the location of the former guardhouse on a sunny day.
media.caption: The gazebo on the location of the former guardhouse that later served as the women’s jail. The parade ground is in the background.  Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: The Guardhouse (includes 2 WS)

media.alt: Commissary and supply wagon on a sunny day.
media.caption: The commissary is the oldest standing building in Fort Smith built in 1849 a replicas supply wagon is front of the commissary during the summer. Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: The Commissary (includes 2 WS outside and 2 WS inside)

media.alt: Aerial view of first fort foundations with river in background
media.caption: Aerial view of the first fort foundation established on December 25, 1817 by the Rifle Regiment. The Arkansas River can be seen in the background.  Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: First Fort Smith

media.alt: Trail of Tears Scenic overlook with river in background.
media.caption: Trail of Tears National Historic Trail scenic overlook recognizes the stories of 5 of 64 different tribes forcibly moved to Indian Territory. The Arkansas River can be seen is the back ground. Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Trail of Tears Scenic Overlook (includes 6 WS)

media.alt: Bastion #4 on a sunny day
media.caption: Bastion #4 facing east was one of five gun emplacements.  Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Bastion #4

media.alt: Bastion #3 on a sunny day
media.caption: Bastion #3 facing southeast was one of 5 gun emplacements. It was converted to the powder magazine and later used as the back support wall of the gallows.
media.name: Bastion #3

media.alt: Gazebo with water fountain
media.caption: Gazebo next to the main has a welcome panel and water fountain.  Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Gazebo by Parking Lot (includes WS)

media.alt: Large American flag flying on a sunny day
media.caption: View of American flying on 99-foot tall flag pole in center of parade ground.  Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Flag Pole (includes Wayside)

media.alt: Bastion #5 on a sunny day
media.caption: Bastion #5 facing northeast was one of 5 gun emplacements.  Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Bastion #5

media.alt: Frisco Train Depot
media.caption: Frisco Train Depot was used from the early 1900s to the mid-1940s. Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Frisco Train Depot

media.alt: Cement slab is one of two that represent the location of the officer’s quarters and garden
media.caption: Cement slab is one of two that represent the location of the officer’s quarters. The Officer’s garden can be seen in the background.  Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Second Fort Smith Officers Quarters #2

media.alt: Garden with flowers and vegetables on a sunny day
media.caption: The Officer’s Wives and children maintained garden with herbs and vegetables to supplement their diet of military rations.   Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Officers' Garden (includes WS)

media.alt: The cistern
media.caption: The original cistern was used to collect fresh water for the Officer’s quarters.   Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Cistern

media.alt: Cement slab is one of two that represent the location of the officer’s quarters.
media.caption: Cement slab is one of two that represent the location of the officer’s quarters.  Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Second Fort Smith Officers Quarters #1 (includes WS)

media.alt: Bass Reeve Statue
media.caption: Bass Reeve Statue in Pendergraft park. Not on Park property.  Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Bass Reeves Statue

media.alt: Isaac C. Parker Federal Courthouse
media.caption: Isaac C. Parker Federal Courthouse located at the cornner of 6 street and Rogers Ave. Not on Park property.  Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Isaac C. Parker Federal Courthouse

media.alt: Entrance to Fort Smith National Cemetery
media.caption: Fort Smith National Cemetery located at 6 street and Garland Ave.  Not on Park property.  Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Fort Smith National Cemetery

media.alt: Fort Smith Museum of History
media.caption: Fort Smith Museum of History located at the corner of 4 street and Rogers Ave.Not on Park property.  Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Fort Smith Museum of History

media.alt: Grave marker Major Bradford
media.caption: Grave markers for Major Bradford and surgeon Russell are located in the Fort Smith National Cemetery Not on Park property.  Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Grave markers of Major William Bradford and surgeon Thomas Russell

media.alt: Fort Smith Trolley Museum is located on 4 street and Garland Ave Not on Park property.  Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.caption: Fort Smith Trolley Museum is located on 4 street and Garland Ave Not on Park property.  Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Fort Smith Trolley Museum

media.alt: Grave marker Isaac C. Parker.
media.caption: Grave marker for Judge Isaac C.Parker is located in the Fort Smith National Cemetery Not on Park property.  Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Grave Marker Issac C. Parker

media.alt: Aerial view of the jail, barracks, courthouse, and parade ground on a sunny day.
media.caption: Aerial view of the jail, barracks, and courthouse looking across the parade ground from across the railroad tracks. The modern jail (1888) is closest with the barracks and courthouse at the far end. Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Aerial view of the jail, barracks, courthouse, and parade ground on a sunny day.

media.alt: Reproduction of gallows with two nooses
media.caption: Reproduction gallows on the site of the original gallows where 86 men were executed. Nooses are on hung on the anniversaries of executions. Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Reproduction of gallows with two nooses

media.alt: The gazebo on the location of the former guardhouse on a sunny day.
media.caption: The gazebo on the location of the former guardhouse that later served as the women’s jail. The memorial wall and bastion number 4 are in the background. Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: The gazebo on the location of the former guardhouse on a sunny day.

media.alt: Exhibits representing the Hamersley home.
media.caption: From 1890-1896 the Hamersley family lived on the first floor of the commissary and the exhibits represent what might have been in their home. Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Exhibits representing the Hamersley home.

media.alt: Reproduction cannon and flag pole at first Fort Smith.
media.caption: Reproduction cannon and flag pole as seen from the sidewalk approaching the foundation of the first Fort Smith established on December 25, 1817 by the Rifle Regiment. Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Reproduction cannon and flag pole at first Fort Smith.

media.alt: Trail of Tears Scenic overlook with river in background.
media.caption: Trail of Tears National Historic Trail scenic overlook recognizes the stories of 5 of 64 different tribes forcibly moved to Indian Territory. The Arkansas River can be seen is the back ground. Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Trail of Tears Scenic overlook with river in background.

media.alt: Frisco Train Depot
media.caption: Frisco Train Depot was used from the early 1900s to the mid-1940s. Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Frisco Train Depot

media.alt: Grave marker Thomas Russell
media.caption: Grave marker Thomas Russell
media.name: Grave marker Thomas Russell

media.alt: Aerial view of reproduction gallows
media.caption: Aerial view of reproduction gallows on the site of the original gallows where 86 men were executed. Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Aerial view of reproduction gallows

media.alt: Exhibits with reproductions of supplies used by soldiers in the 1850s.
media.caption: From 1846 to 1871, the stored supplies for soldiers in Fort Smith and forts in Indian Territory. Parts of the exhibits are  the supplies used by soldiers in the 1850s. . Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Exhibits with reproductions of supplies used by soldiers in the 1850s.

media.alt: Aerial view of blockhouse foundation looking north
media.caption: Aerial view of the blockhouse foundation from the First Fort Smith foundation established on December 25, 1817 by the Rifle Regiment. Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Aerial view of blockhouse foundation looking north

media.alt: Close-up of initial point marker
media.caption: The initial point marker was the starting point for the boundary survey of the border between Arkansas and Choctaw Territory. Photo Credit FOSM NPS
media.name: Close-up of initial point marker

pages.description: This is the Special Info page!
pages.name: Hiking Info

name: Fort Smith

sites.description: Established on Christmas Day 1817 when the first soldiers arrived to begin building. Their assignment was to stop the fighting between the long established Osage and newly arriving Cherokees moving into Indian Territory. Interesting Fact: Fort Smith was located on the edge of the United States at that time. Far removed from other towns and supply resources, the first soldiers had to be self-sufficient during long periods of time between supply shipments.
sites.name: First Fort Smith
sites.name_description: Established on Christmas Day 1817 by the U.S. military to ensure peace between the Cherokee and Osage.

sites.description: Under the Indian Removal Act of 1830, the U.S. government using treaties exchanged tribal lands in the east belonging to Choctaws, Cherokees, Chickasaws, Muscogee (Creeks), and Seminoles for land west of the Mississippi River. This removal process left a bitter legacy remembered today as the Trail of Tears. From 1830-1842 each of the Five Tribes traveled various land and water routes to Indian Territory (today Oklahoma). Groups from each tribe traveled the Arkansas River, stopped in the Fort Smith area and received supplies before reaching their destinations. These are just five of the 64 tribes removed from their ancestral homelands to Indian Territory.
sites.name: Trail of Tears Scenic Overlook (includes 6 WS)
sites.name_description: Scenic view of Arkansas River offering interpretive panels featuring five tribal perspectives of Indian removal.

sites.name: Miss Laura's Visitor Center
sites.name_description: A former bordello, Fort Smith's official welcome center open Mon.-Sat. from 9 a.m. – 4 p.m. and Sun. 1 p.m. - 4:30 p.m.

sites.name: River Front Park
sites.name_description: Operated by the City of Fort Smith, on the bank of the Arkansas River, the amphitheater hosts concerts and other events.

sites.name: Bass Reeves Statue
sites.name_description: This larger than life bronze statue is dedicated to Deputy US Marshal Bass Reeves and his faithful dog.

sites.name: Gazebo near First Fort (Includes 3 WS)
sites.name_description: The panels discuss the founding of Fort Smith and those who served here from 1817-1824.

sites.name: Flag of First Fort
sites.name_description: The first flag to fly over Fort Smith had 15 stars and 15 stripes, one for each state.

sites.name: Fort Smith National Cemetery
sites.name_description: National Cemetery for veterans from the War of 1812 to present. Open daily 7:30am to sunset.

sites.name: Fort Smith Museum of History (Does this need AD?)
sites.name_description: The museum focuses on the Fort Smith community, includes an operating soda fountain.  Open Tue - Sat 10-5 and Sun 12-5.

sites.name: Second Fort Smith Officers Quarters #1 (includes WS)
sites.name_description: One of two officers quarters constructed and used from 1838-1871. By 1870, chimney fires destroyed both buildings.

sites.name: Bastion #2 (includes Initial Point Marker and Belle Point Historical Marker)
sites.name_description: The quartermaster’s storehouse was built on top of the bastion. Nearby is a survey marker for the Arkansas border.

sites.name: Block House of First Fort
sites.name_description: Built by soldiers, the blockhouse was a defensive structure. All that remains is the foundation.

sites.name: U.S. Marshall’s Museum Administrative Offices (Does this need AD?)
sites.name_description: Current location of the US Marshal Museum administrative offices, education, and fund-raising activities.

sites.name: Fort Smith Trolley Museum (Does this need AD?)
sites.name_description: Museum dedicated to Fort Smith's early street cars and railroad history. Seasonal hours. Call (479) 783-0205.

sites.name: Defending Freedom (WS)
sites.name_description: During the Civil War, four regiments of United States Colored Troops served in here, including one unit from the city.

sites.name: Fort Wall (WS)
sites.name_description: Originally, the fort was surrounded by a stone wall 12’ high and 2’ feet thick. This fort was one of the last this type.

sites.description: Currently serving as the park’s Visitor Center, the building has served many purposes and undergone major architectural changes through the years. It was originally built as a one-story structure with basement during the second Fort Smith period (1838-1871). It served as the enlisted soldiers’ barracks and basement dining room. During the Federal Court period (1872-1896), the barracks became the courtroom, the basement became the “Hell on the Border” jail, and a second story was added. In 1888, the building changed again with the completion of a new three-story jail. Tour the building to experience the first jail and see first- hand why it earned the nickname of being “Hell on the Border”, and compare the improvement of conditions with the construction of the second jail. There are exhibits about tough outlaws, tougher lawmen, and the toughest of them all, Judge Isaac C. Parker. Other exhibits explore Fort Smith’s role in Westward Expansion and Federal Indian Policy.
sites.name: Barracks, Courthouse, Jail (WS) / Visitor Center
sites.name_description: Park’s Visitor Center, served as a soldiers’ barracks (1838-1871), converted to jail and courthouse in 1872.

sites.description: Why execution by hanging? At the time, hanging was considered the most humane method of execution. When done properly, the neck is broken and death comes quickly.Murder, rape, treason, and obstruction of an execution were the only Federal crimes with an automatic death sentence. In Fort Smith, 81 men were hanged for murder and 5 for rape. Crowds in the thousands came to Fort Smith to watch the earlier executions before the fence was erected. Executions became private two years after Judge Parker arrived. In order to attend an execution one had to get permission from the U.S. Marshal by providing a reason to be there. Those who attended executions included reporters, clergy, medical personnel, family members of both the victim and the condemned.  The current gallows are a reproduction based on images and historic records. The original gallows was destroyed by the city of Fort Smith in 1897 because of the negative reputation it gave the city. Today the gallows stand as a stark reminder of the struggle for justice on the western frontier.
sites.name: The Gallows (includes 2 WS)
sites.name_description: Reproduction built on the location of the original gallows. From 1872 to 1896, 86 men were executed here.

sites.description: The guardhouse, constructed in 1849, was a focal point of daily activity at the second Fort Smith serving as the initial check-in point for soldiers, supplies, and visitors. The guardhouse was also the place of confinement for soldiers under arrest for such offenses as drunkenness, desertion, or fighting. After the U.S. Army closed Fort Smith in 1871, the federal court converted the guardhouse into a jail for women.   If a female prisoner had a child and no family members or friends to take care of the child, he or she went to jail too. During the day, the children were allowed to play on the grounds. We know of at least to two children who served time with their mothers.  Crimes committed by women ranged from the illegal sale of whiskey to murder. When convicted, they received the same sentences as men – fines, jail time, or death by hanging. Although four women were sentenced to hang, none were executed at Fort Smith.
sites.name: The Guardhouse (includes 2 WS)
sites.name_description: Guardhouse/jail for 2nd Fort Smith (1838-1871), became the women's jail during Federal Court period (1872-1896).

sites.description: In 1845, Quartermaster General Thomas Jesup inspected Fort Smith and ordered the fort to be converted into a supply depot. With its new mission, Fort Smith became one of the largest and busiest supply posts in the south.The commissary is the oldest building still standing in Fort Smith. Over the years its appearance and use changed dramatically. The building held food supplies for soldiers in Fort Smith and forts further west.  From 1875 – 1890, Federal Judge Isaac C. Parker’s office was on the second floor. The Hamersley family used the first floor as their home from 1890-1896.Today, the commissary is furnished with reproductions of supplies that the U.S. Army stored there in the 1850’s and as the 1890 Hamersley home.
sites.name: The Commissary (includes 2 WS outside and 2 WS inside)
sites.name_description: Built in 1846, when the fort’s mission shifted from defensive to a supply depot.

sites.name: Isaac C. Parker Federal Courthouse
sites.name_description: Named for Judge Isaac C. Parker, this building is the current federal courthouse for the Western District of Arkansas.

sites.name: Gazebo by Parking Lot (includes WS)
sites.name_description: Welcome to Fort Smith National Historic Site, the remains of two military forts and a federal court are preserved here.

sites.name: Frisco Train Depot
sites.name_description: Frisco Train Depot was used from the early 1900s to the mid-1940s.

sites.name: Second Fort Smith Officers Quarters #2
sites.name_description: One of two officers quarters constructed and used from 1838-1871. By 1870, chimney fires destroyed both buildings.

sites.name: Officers' Garden (includes WS)
sites.name_description: The officers' garden is a re-creation of the 1860's garden. The officers’ wives and children cared for the garden.

sites.name: Welcome to Fort Smith - Main Entrance (WS)
sites.name_description: Welcome to Fort Smith National Historic Site, the remains of two military forts and a federal court are preserved here.

sites.name: Welcome to Fort Smith - Near Maintenance Building (WS)
sites.name_description: Welcome to Fort Smith National Historic Site, the remains of two military forts and a federal court are preserved here.

sites.name: The Parade Ground (WS)
sites.name_description: From 1846-1871 soldiers performed drill and ceremonies on the parade grounds, making it the center of life at the fort.

sites.name: A Disputed Boundary (WS)
sites.name_description: The boundary between Arkansas and Choctaw territory was originally incorrect due to a survey error.

sites.name: Whiskey War (WS)
sites.name_description: Soldiers fired a cannon in to the Bigalows tavern after the Bigalows beat-up the fort’s commander.

sites.name: Abandoned and Forgotten (WS)
sites.name_description: A pencil drawing of the first Fort Smith superimposed on a modern picture of the fort’s foundations.

sites.name: Request Denied (WS)
sites.name_description: In April 1821, 400 Osage warriors attempted to attack Fort Smith, hoping to scare the soldiers.

sites.name: Pioneering Solders (WS)
sites.name_description: Along with their military duties, soldiers were responsible for hunting, gardening, and building the fort.

sites.name: Osage Nation (WS)
sites.name_description: Over 72 years the Osage were forced through treaties to surrender a majority of their homeland.

sites.name: Confederates Occupy (WS)
sites.name_description: On Apr. 22, 1861, Union troops abandoned Fort Smith. Arkansas State Troops took over the fort the next day.

sites.name: Meeting of Nations (WS)
sites.name_description: Treated as the enemy,  12 tribes met with the US Government to agree on post Civil War treaties, which were signed in 1866.

sites.name: Desperate for Survival (WS)
sites.name_description: From 1863-1865, the riverfront landing was often filled with refugees  hoping to escape the devastation of Civil War.

sites.name: Flag Pole (includes Wayside)
sites.name_description: The flagpole (99 ft.) is a reproduction of the original built in 1846. This height allows the flag to be seen for miles.

sites.name: Cistern
sites.name_description: Before running water and indoor plumbing, soldiers dug this cistern in 1869 to collect rainwater.

sites.name: Grave Marker Issac C. Parker
sites.name_description: Located in the Fort Smith National Cemetery, the white headstone is inscribed with just his name and grave number.

sites.name: Bastion #4
sites.name_description: One of five bastions or gun emplacements that would have defended the fort if attacked.

sites.name: Bastion #3
sites.name_description: One of five bastions or gun emplacements that would have defended the fort if attacked

sites.name: Bastion #5
sites.name_description: One of five bastions or gun emplacements that would have defended the fort if attacked

sites.name: Grave markers of Major William Bradford and surgeon Thomas Russell (Do these need AD?)
sites.name_description: Fort Smith's earliest grave markers, Major William Bradford, and surgeon Thomas Russell. Both War of 1812 Veterans.
